utterances: She say two years ago, Jose's father and his mother, who was five months pregnant at the time, were murdered for refusing to cooperate with local drug traffickers - one reason we've agreed not to use their full names or to identify which of three troubled Central American countries Jose is from - El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras.
Jose's three younger siblings remain in his village living on their own.
(Spanish spoken).
Marta says there are no laws in her country - that the police only come when the bodies are being buried.
So the family pulled together $4,000 to get Jose out before it was too late.
He says he gave himself up at the Texas border and spent eight days at a detention center where it was dark and cold.

Now the teen sits at Mary's Center in Prince George's County, Maryland wearing black and white Converse sneakers, khaki shorts and a T-shirt that has pictures of surfboards on it and the words Santa Cruz, California.
(Spanish spoken).
Jose says he feels safe now, but he's worried about his siblings back home.
His sister is 15.
His brothers are 11 and 7.
Maria Gomez, who runs Mary's Center, says stories like Jose's are not uncommon.
So far almost every single one of the kids that we've gotten has been through some horrendous trauma.
She says many of the children have been physically or sexually abused at home or along the way here.
She says one 11-year-old girl was raped by the men her family paid to bring her to the U.S.
And now she's pregnant.
One of the many who's, like - can't even talk anymore - can't even talk.
She has no idea what it all means, but she knows - carrying this baby.
And the tragedy of it all is that the parents are so overwhelmed because they left her back home when she was an infant, and now they don't know how to handle her now.
So she's being blamed for getting pregnant.
Other agencies say they're seeing similar cases - children with layer upon layer of problems that will need to be dealt with soon.
Groups like Mary's Center have been meeting with state and local agencies trying to figure out who can do what and how they can work together.
Although they're somewhat hampered because the federal government can't tell them how many more children will arrive and when.
I think the biggest concern I would have is our capacity because our programs are already filled.
Tom Harr is CEO of Family Services, a nonprofit agency in Montgomery County, Maryland.
So far more that 2,200 unaccompanied children have been placed in Maryland homes.
Harr says it will be a challenge getting them the help they need.
Some programs - you can't provide services if people are undocumented.
Mental health is a tough one.
And that is expected to be one of the kid's biggest needs.
Daliris Amaya is a youth and family counselor with Family Services.
She's already working with newly arrived immigrant children at a local high school.
She says many of them are angry and confused, especially if they've rejoined parents who fled their countries years ago.
They haven't met mom, like, in 10 years.
So that's a complete, you know, stranger to them.
I have had cases that my clients didn't have a clue that mom was pregnant or that mom had another, you know, child.
And when they come here, you know - surprise, you have another sibling.
On top of all the other stresses of being in a new country and not knowing if they'll be sent back home, Maria Gomez of Mary's Center says her biggest fear is that these kids will become prey to U.S.
gangs like those they were trying to flee.
(Spanish spoken).
For now Jose's Aunt Marta is more worried about finding him a lawyer and healthcare.
She also plans to enroll him in high school.
Although back home, Jose stopped going to school in third grade.
That's a challenge for another day.
Pam Fessler, NPR News, Washington.
Another hope for good health that's becoming more and more popular is kombucha, which is a fermented brew of sweetened tea and bacteria.
Consumers are hoping the drink will help them fight off disease, improve energy and even inhibit aging.
NPR's Patti Neighmond looks at what we do and do not know about kombucha.
The bottles are artsy and colorful, the flavors varied; citrus, watermelon, ginger.
And the taste, well, acquired.
For me it's sort of like a vinegar soda, in a way.
Like it has like an effervescence to it.
Brian Smith gets his kombucha tea at a local grocery store in Washington, D.C., So does Erin Upton-Cosulich.
The taste is a little bit like beer, kind of tangy and a little bit sweet.
Kombucha is a mixture of black or green tea, sugar, yeast and bacteria.
And consumers like Annie Sprengelmeyer say it just makes them feel better.
It gives you a little bit of a different kind mind clearing.
For me it just kind of wakes me up.
Lots of kombucha drinkers describe a similar energy boost or sense of well-being, but bottom line, we just don't know very much about kombucha.
And some of the benefits touted, says nutritionist Monica Reinagel, go way too far.
I've seen claims that kombucha will help cure cancer, that it's a powerful detoxifier, that it's the fountain of youth.
Pretty hefty claims and pretty unlikely, says registered dietitian Andrea Giancoli, spokesperson for the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics.
There is really very little evidence to support any kind of claims of kombucha tea.
We don't know if it does anything at all.
But because most kombucha drinks contains live bacteria, there could be certain health benefits.
Evidence is mounting that friendly bacteria or probiotics aid in digestion and possibly even strengthen the immune system.
Nutritionist Monica Reinagel.
They actually live inside of us and they help digest our food.
They actually produce certain nutrients for us, which is a very nice trick.
The proposed regulations would place a near-total ban on anything made with ivory moving in and out of the United States.
Craig Hoover heads up the Wildlife Trade and Conservation Branch of the U.S.
Fish and Wildlife Service.
And all of these things, of course, well, you know, at some level, you got to carry your diapers around in something.
Nevertheless, this may turn out to be useful.
But there are all these services available too.

And you write that many parents have now come to believe that to do it themselves would require an art shop worth of supplies and formal training that they - to give their kids a chance in the world that they're going to live in, they have to start them in classes as soon as, what, four months old?
Oh, absolutely.
I mean, what happens is there's this kind of tyranny of - that's a combination of competition and anxiety of underspending that, you know, how can you skimp on spending something for your child?
Because I think what's happened is that in our parenting consumer culture, caring for your child has often become translated into buying something for your child.

And there's this idea that, well, if - even if I abstain and all these other kids are going to jamboree and music together and they're learning baby sign language, well then what does that mean for my kid, you know, is my kid going to fall behind?
Yeah.
You open your book with your husband and yourself, arguing with yourselves about this idea: should you spend the money to have your baby learn sign?
Yeah.

And, you know, the idea behind it - I mean, there are many reasons that baby in designing industry will tell you that you should have your babies learn how to sign before they can talk, enrolling them in a class at 7 or 8 months.
One of the reasons they give is that you will eliminate frustration.
But if you think about that, I mean, why eliminate frustration?

You know, why - you know, they say, well, your nine-month-old is sitting there and you're now going blah, blah, blah and you don't know if they're, you know, they're constipated or if their diaper needs changing.
And so, you know, supposedly, you can teach them signs that will enable them to tell you what it is they want.
But why do you want to eliminate frustration?
I mean, I don't know about, you but I'm frustrated every day.
You know, being frustrated is something human beings have to learn to deal with.
And out of that comes resourcefulness and invention, and motivation, and so I don't know why we would want to not have our children learn how to deal with that.

And as long as they can't communicate, parents can indulge the idea that inside that chrome dome, some profound thoughts are rattling around in there, only to realize when their children do learn to communicate that these are pretty basic urges that they're thinking about.
Right.

And the thing as is if you're sitting down and you're teaching them baby sign language, okay, and you're occupying them with all of that, it's as if we think that parent, you know, babies are on the sort of one-track-path to, you know, cognitive development, to speaking aloud.
Whereas, they might, in that time, be busy just, you know, figuring out that if you put a cup on a table it doesn't sinks through and fall to the floor.
And, you know, that's what they need to be doing during that time.
We're talking with Pamela Paul.

Her book is ""Parenting Inc: How We Are Sold on $800 Strollers, Fetal Education, Baby Sign Language, Sleeping Coaches, Toddler Couture and Diaper Wipe Warmers - and What It All Means for Our Children.
800-989-8255 if you'd like to join us.
E-mail: talk@npr.org.
Lindy(ph) is on the line calling from Sioux City in Iowa.
Hi, how are you doing today?
Very well, thanks.
